"[[Afternoon Delight (song)|Afternoon Delight]]" | Episode list = [[List of Glee episodes|List of ''Glee'' episodes]] | Prev = [[Blame It on the Alcohol]] | Next = [[Original Song]] }} "'''Sexy'''" is the fifteenth episode of the [[Glee (season 2)|second season]] of the American television series ''[[Glee (TV series)|Glee]]'', and the 37th overall. It was written by [[Brad Falchuk]], directed by [[Ryan Murphy (writer)|Ryan Murphy]], and premiered on [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] on March 8, 2011. This episode mainly revolves around the topics of [[sex]] and [[adolescent sexuality]]. In this episode, [[Holly Holliday]] ([[Gwyneth Paltrow]]) returns to McKinley High School as a substitute teacher in a class devoted to [[sex education]]. The school glee club director [[Will Schuester]] ([[Matthew Morrison]]) begins to develop deep feelings for Holliday, and the guidance counselor and celibacy club advisor [[Emma Pillsbury]] ([[Jayma Mays]]) is less than pleased with Holly's lessons. Meanwhile, [[Santana Lopez|Santana]] ([[Naya Rivera]]) expresses her love for [[Brittany Pierce|Brittany]] ([[Heather Morris (actress)|Heather Morris]]), and [[Burt Hummel]] ([[Mike O'Malley]]) has a talk with his son [[Kurt Hummel|Kurt]] ([[Chris Colfer]]) about sex. "Sexy" was met with generally positive reviews from critics and fans alike. Many critics went on to praise Paltrow's performance, preferring it to her first appearance in "[[The Substitute (Glee)|The Substitute]]". However, they disagreed over how Paltrow was used. The storylines were met with general acclaim, particularly the plot between Brittany and Santana. Critics such as Todd VanDerWerff of ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' and Patrick Burns of ''[[The Atlantic]]'' deemed the storyline as the highlight of the episode. This episode featured [[cover versions]] of five songs, including a cover of "[[Kiss (song)|Kiss]]" by [[Prince (musician)|Prince]] and "[[Landslide (song)|Landslide]]" by [[Fleetwood Mac]]. The musical performances and cover versions in the episode had a mixed reception from critics. Upon its original airing, this episode was viewed by 11.92 million American viewers, and garnered a 4.6/14 [[Nielsen ratings#Ratings/share and total viewers|Nielsen rating/share]] in the [[Nielsen ratings#Demographics|18â49 demographic]], according to the [[Nielsen ratings]]. The episode's total viewership and ratings increased significantly from the previous episode, "[[Blame It on the Alcohol]]", which was viewed by 10.58 million American viewers, and it acquired a 4.4/12 rating/share in the 18â49 demographic. ==Plot== Substitute teacher [[Holly Holliday]] ([[Gwyneth Paltrow]]) returns to McKinley High to cover [[sex education]] classes, and tells [[Will Schuester]] ([[Matthew Morrison]]), director of the school [[glee club]] New Directions, that his club members are among the most ignorant about sex. He asks her to educate them using song, so Holly performs [[Joan Jett]]'s cover of "[[Do You Wanna Touch Me#Joan Jett version|Do You Wanna Touch Me (Oh Yeah)]]". Will later rehearses a rendition of [[Prince (musician)|Prince]]'s "[[Kiss (song)|Kiss]]" with her, which culminates in a kiss, but Holly will not go further as she believes she would end up hurting him. [[Sue Sylvester]] ([[Jane Lynch]]), director of rival glee club Aural Intensity, seeks out former New Directions member and current Dalton Academy Warbler [[Kurt Hummel]] ([[Chris Colfer]]) to tell him and his friend [[Blaine Anderson|Blaine]] ([[Darren Criss]]), the Warblers' lead singer, that New Directions is planning a sexually provocative routine for the upcoming Regionals competition, having heard that the judges will be looking for same. Blaine responds by having the Warblers work up a "sexified" performance of "[[Animal (Neon Trees song)|Animal]]" by [[Neon Trees]], with Kurt joining him on lead, but Kurtâs "sexy" faces and moves are anything but. Kurt insists on remaining ignorant of sexual matters, which Blaine feels is dangerous at their age, so he visits Kurt's father, [[Burt Hummel|Burt]] ([[Mike O'Malley]]), and prompts him to give Kurt "[[The birds and the bees|the talk]]" about sex. At McKinley, glee club members [[Puck (Glee)|Puck]] ([[Mark Salling]]) and [[Lauren Zizes|Lauren]] ([[Ashley Fink]]) plan to make a [[sex tape]], until Holly informs them that it would be considered [[child pornography]]. Puck, appalled, joins the celibacy club. The club's advisor [[Emma Pillsbury]] ([[Jayma Mays]]) thinks Holly's lessons are inappropriate, so she arranges for the club to perform a wholesome song for New Directions. She picks [[Starland Vocal Band]]'s "[[Afternoon Delight (song)|Afternoon Delight]]", unaware that the song is about sex. Her husband [[Carl Howell|Carl]] ([[John Stamos]]) approaches Holly afterward about counseling. During the counseling session, he reveals that Emma is still a virgin, and Emma admits that she may still have feelings for Will. Carl tells her he will be moving into a hotel until she is certain of her feelings. Holly also counsels glee club members [[Santana Lopez|Santana]] ([[Naya Rivera]]) and [[Brittany Pierce|Brittany]] ([[Heather Morris (actress)|Heather Morris]]) when they express confusion about their sexuality. She joins them for a performance of "[[Landslide (song)|Landslide]]" by [[Fleetwood Mac]], after which Santana tearfully confesses that she is in love with Brittany and wants to be with her. However, after Kurt's experience as an openly [[homosexual|gay]] student at McKinley, Santana is afraid of being bullied and ostracized by the student body for being in a [[same-sex relationship]]. Brittany reciprocates her love, but explains that she also loves her boyfriend [[Artie Abrams|Artie]] ([[Kevin McHale (actor)|Kevin McHale]]) and will not break up with him, to Santana's distress. Lauren is annoyed with Puck for joining the celibacy club, but when he explains that he is trying to take responsibility for his actions, she kisses him and agrees to join too. [[Quinn Fabray|Quinn]] ([[Dianna Agron]]) shows up at the club meeting with a hickey on her neck from making out with [[Finn Hudson|Finn]] ([[Cory Monteith]]), though she claims the mark is from burning herself with a curling iron. Holly's stint as a sex education instructor ends when parents complain about her classes. She tells Will that she wants to learn about romance; he offers to teach her, and they kiss. ==Production== [[File:GwynethPaltrowTIFF00 adj.jpg|thumb|right|140px|In "Sexy", Paltrow (''pictured'') reprised her role as substitute teacher Holly Holliday.]] "Sexy" marked Paltrow's second guest appearance on ''Glee'' as substitute teacher Holly Holliday. She originally appeared in "[[The Substitute (Glee)|The Substitute]]", episode seven of the second season.{{cite web|url=http://www.etonline.com/tv/108097_New_Details_on_Gwyneth_Paltrow_s_Glee_Return_Revealed/|title=New Details on Gwyneth Paltrow's 'Glee' Return Revealed!|last=|first=|date=March 8, 2011|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Time, Inc.]]|accessdate=February 24, 2011}} The role was devised for her by series creator [[Ryan Murphy (writer)|Ryan Murphy]], who suggested that she showcase her vocal and dancing talent ahead of the release of the film ''[[Country Strong]]'', in which Paltrow plays a [[country singer]].{{cite web|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/moviestvmusic/news/new-details-on-gwyneth-paltrows-upcoming-glee-gig-2010279|title=New Details on Gwyneth Paltrow's Upcoming Glee Gig|date=September 27, 2010|work=[[Us Weekly]]|publisher=[[Wenner Media]]|accessdate=November 18, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20440862,00.html|title=Glee Creator: Gwyneth Paltrow Pulls Off 'Really Hard Dance Number'|first=Nadine|last=Shabeeb|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|publisher=[[Time Inc]]|date=November 10, 2010|accessdate=November 18, 2010}} Paltrow was signed to ''Glee'' for two episodes,{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-11389291|title=Gwyneth Paltrow to appear in Glee|first=Genevieve|last=Hassan|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=September 22, 2010|accessdate=November 18, 2010}} with "The Substitute" originally intended to feature a love quadrangle between Holly, Will, Emma and Carl.{{cite web|url=http://uk.eonline.com/photos/gallery.jsp?galleryUUID=2515#91611|title=TV Spoiler Chat, Oct. 4|work=[[E! Online]]|publisher=[[Comcast]]|date=October 4, 2010|accessdate=November 18, 2010}} Her initial arc was, however, reduced to a single episode.{{cite web|url=http://www.fancast.com/blogs/2010/tv-news/gwyneth-does-glee-the-latest-on-her-censored-tune-and-more/|title=Gwyneth Does âGleeâ: The Latest On Her Censored Tune And More|first=Matt|last=Mitovich|date=November 4, 2010|work=Fancast|publisher=[[Comcast Interactive Media]]|accessdate=November 18, 2010}} Post-broadcast, Murphy said they both hoped she would appear on ''Glee'' again in the future, depending on the right storyline.{{cite web|url=http://uk.eonline.com/uberblog/watch_with_kristin/b211784_will_gwyneth_paltrow_return_glee_ryan.html|title=Will Gwyneth Paltrow Return to Glee? Ryan Murphy Tells Us|first=Kristin|last=dos Santos|authorlink=Kristin dos Santos|work=[[E! Online]]|publisher=[[Comcast]]|date=November 17, 2010|accessdate=November 17, 2010}} In January 2011, Paltrow confirmed that she would be reprising the role.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/video/watch/?id=7218980n|title=Gwyneth Paltrow to Return to "Glee"|last=Hill|first=Erica|date=March 8, 2011|work=[[The Early Show]]|publisher=[[CBS]]|accessdate=January 6, 2011}} Murphy stated that she would appear in episodes fifteen and sixteen as a sex education teacher, and would serve as a love interest for Will,{{Cite news|url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2011/01/08/glee-exclusive-gwyneth-paltrow-ladygaga/|title={{-'}}Glee' exclusives: Seasons 2 to feature more Gwyneth and Gaga!|date=January 8, 2011|first=Tim|last=Stack|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Time Inc]]|accessdate=January 8, 2011}} though she actually appeared in episodes fifteen and seventeen. Stamos also reprised his role as Emma's husband Carl. As of March 2011, he was unsure whether he would return to ''Glee'' again, but stated that he might do so to conclude Emma and Carl's storyline, explaining: "I think people like me on there, but they really love Will and Emma together. So I don't know how much longer people can stand Will and Emma not being together."{{cite web|url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2011/03/08/john-stamos-glee-bones-spoilers/|title=John Stamos on 'Glee,' 'SVU,' plus 'Parks and Rec,' 'Bones,' and 'Vampire Diaries': Find out what's next in the Spoiler Room|last=Gonzalez|first=Sandra|date=March 8, 2011|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Time Inc]]|accessdate=March 9, 2011}} The episode continued the romantic relationship between Brittany and Santana, first alluded to during the [[Glee (season 1)|first season]].{{cite web|url=http://www.celebuzz.com/glees-hot-girl-girl-kiss-s261551/|title='Glee's' Hot Girl-On-Girl Kiss!|date=October 13, 2010|work=[[Celebuzz]]|publisher=[[Buzz Media]]|accessdate=October 13, 2010}} The two kissed on-screen for the first time in the season two episode "[[Duets (Glee)|Duets]]", after which their romance was little explored, leading to what Rivera described as an "uproar" by fans of the pairing in December 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.afterellen.com/TV/2010/12/the-evolution-and-devolution-of-brittana-on-glee|title=The evolution and devolution of Brittana on "Glee"|last=Snarker|first=Dorothy|date=December 10, 2011|work=[[AfterEllen.com]]|publisher=[[Logo (TV channel)|Logo]]|accessdate=March 9, 2011}} The following month, executive producer [[Brad Falchuk]] revealed via the social networking website [[Twitter]] that further developments to the storyline had always been intended, with Paltrow's Holly serving as a catalyst.{{cite web|url=http://uk.eonline.com/uberblog/watch_with_kristin/b222228_spoiler_chat_glee_castle_greys_anatomy.html|title=Spoiler Chat: Glee, Castle, Grey's Anatomy, 90210, and More!|last=dos Santos|first=Kristin|authorlink=Kristin dos Santos|date=January 24, 2011|work=[[E! Online]]|accessdate=March 9, 2011}} In addition to Paltrow reprising her role as Holly Holliday, recurring characters who appear on the episode include Stamos as dentist Carl Howell, football coach [[Shannon Beiste]] ([[Dot-Marie Jones]]), glee club members Lauren Zizes, [[Sam Evans]] ([[Chord Overstreet]]) and [[Mike Chang]] ([[Harry Shum, Jr.]]), and Kurt's friend Blaine Anderson. ==Reception== ===Ratings=== "Sexy" was first broadcast on March 8, 2011 in the United States on Fox. It was watched by 11.92 million American viewers upon its initial airing, according to the [[Nielsen ratings]], despite airing simultaneously with ''[[The Biggest Loser: Couples 4|The Biggest Loser]]'' on [[NBC]], ''[[No Ordinary Family]]'' on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]], ''[[NCIS (TV series)|NCIS]]'' on [[CBS]], and ''[[One Tree Hill (TV series)|One Tree Hill]]'' on [[The CW]]. It attained a 4.6/14 [[Nielsen ratings#Ratings/share and total viewers|Nielsen rating/share]] in the [[Nielsen ratings#Demographics|18â49 demographic]], making it the highest rated show of the night.{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2011/03/09/tuesday-final-ratings-raising-hope-adjusted-down-no-adjustments-for-v/85185/|title=Tuesday Final Ratings: 'Raising Hope' Adjusted Down; No Adjustments for 'V"|last=Seidman|first=Robert|date=March 9, 2011|work=TV by the Numbers|accessdate=June 12, 2011}} It increased by over 1.4 million viewers and 5 percent in the 18â49 ratings on the previous episode, "[[Blame It on the Alcohol]]".{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2011/02/24/tuesday-final-ratings-glee-adjusted-up-ties-ncis-the-good-wife-adjusted-up-raising-hope-traffic-light-adjusted-down/83561/|title=Tuesday Final Ratings: 'Glee' Adjusted Up, Ties 'NCIS'; 'The Good Wife' Adjusted Up; 'Raising Hope,' 'Traffic Light' Adjusted Down|last=Siedman|first=Robert|date=February 22, 2011|work=Tv by the Numbers|publisher=TVbytheNumbers.com|accessdate=June 12, 2011}} In Australia, the episode was watched by 1.03 million viewers, making ''Glee'' the eighth most-watched show of the night.{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/opinion/blogs/the-tribal-mind/the-ratings-race-alicia-finally-beats-the-despos/20110314-1btf9.html|title=THE RATINGS RACE: Alicia finally beats the Despos|last=Dale|first=David|date=March 14, 2011|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|publisher=[[Fairfax Media]]|accessdate=March 19, 2011}} In the UK, the episode was watched by 2.58 million viewers (2.039 million on [[E4 (channel)|E4]], and 541,000 on E4+1), becoming the most-watched show on cable for the week.{{Cite web |url=http://www.barb.co.uk/report/weeklyTopProgrammesOverview/? |title=Weekly Top 30 Programmes: w/e 24 Apr 2011 |publisher=[[Broadcasters' Audience Research Board|BARB]] |accessdate=May 3, 2011}} ===Critical response=== The episode received a positive response from critics. Reviewers disagreed over how well Paltrow was utilized, but generally praised the BrittanyâSantana and KurtâBlaine storylines. ''[[The Atlantic]]''{{'s}} Kevin Fallon deemed "Sexy" an episode of mixed messages, one which treated the issues it raised with "an appropriate amount of levity", but failed to "play the nuances of the [celibacy vs. sex] argument as delicately as it probably thought it did." His ''Atlantic'' co-writer Patrick Burns criticized the series for glorifying a risquÃ© subject, "then half-heartedly attempt[ing] to hammer home a moral." Meghan Brown, also writing for ''The Atlantic'', called it a "solid episode with some strong character moments." ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''{{'s}} James Poniewozik felt that the episode "began clumsily, lacked subtlety, involved some embarrassing moments" and focused too much on Paltrow, but as it continued, "achieve[d] a few moments of delight and honest emotion."{{cite web|url=http://tunedin.blogs.time.com/2011/03/09/glee-watch-drowning-in-goop/|title=Glee Watch: Drowning in Goop|last=Poniewozik|first=James|date=March 9, 2011|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|publisher=[[Time Inc]]|accessdate=March 9, 2011}} {{quote box |width = 30em |border = 1px |align=right |bgcolor=#c6dbf7 |fontsize = 85% |quote = "Even ''Glee''{{'s}} most outlandish characters are generally anchored in some real conflict that keeps them from utterly floating off into the crazysphere, and gives their dramatic moments some heft. Holly, though, simply has some kind of generic "damage" in her past that's an excuse for her to act out and give some veneer of humanity to her quickly engineered romance with Will." |salign = right |source =âJames Poniewozik of ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'', on Holly Holliday. }} Several critics preferred Paltrow's return in "Sexy" to her first appearance in "The Substitute". ''[[The Washington Post]]''{{'s}} Lisa de Moraes felt that she was better integrated into this episode,{{cite web|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/tvblog/2011/03/glee-gwyneth-paltrow-returns.html|title='Glee': Gwyneth Paltrow returns! And talks about sex!|last=de Moraes|first=Lisa|date=March 9, 2011|work=[[The Washington Post]]|publisher=[[The Washington Post Company]]|accessdate=March 9, 2011}} and Raymund Flandez of the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' called her return "infinitely better" than her first appearance, explaining, "Back then, she was a puzzle, a loony bin. Here, she's sly and quick-witted, appropriately adult and seductively saucy in an episode that showcased more of her comedic timing, than her stiff dance skills. All the better for us."{{cite web|url=http://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2011/03/09/glee-season-2-episode-15-sexy-tv-recap/?mod=google_news_blog|title=âGleeâ Season 2, Episode 15 âSexyâ: TV Recap|last=Flandez|first=Raymund|date=March 9, 2011|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|publisher=[[Dow Jones & Company]]|accessdate=March 9, 2011}} Fallon wrote that Paltrow was "if possible, even sassier and sultrier" than before, and felt that she served to anchor a busy episode.{{cite web|url=http://www.theatlantic.com/culture/archive/2011/03/glee-gwyneth-paltrow-brings-sexy-back/72201/|title='Glee': Gwyneth Paltrow Brings Sexy Back|last=Fallon|first=Kevin|coauthors=Burns, Patrick; Brown, Meghan|date=March 9, 2011|work=[[The Atlantic]]|publisher=[[Atlantic Media Company]]|accessdate=March 9, 2011}} In contrast, Sandra Gonzalez of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' had mixed feelings about Holly, believing that she dominated screen time.{{cite web|url=http://tvrecaps.ew.com/recap/glee-season-2-episode-15-sexy/|title='Glee' recap: Let's Talk About Sex|first=Sandra|last=Gonzalez|date=March 9, 2011|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Time Inc]]|accessdate=March 9, 2011}} Todd VanDerWerff of ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' liked Paltrow's acting, but disliked Holly's interaction with Will, saying they lacked chemistry.{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/sexy,52769/|title=Sexy|first=Todd|last=VanDerWerff|date=March 9, 2011|work=[[The A.V. Club]]|publisher=[[The Onion]]|accessdate=March 9, 2011}} Soraya Roberts of the ''[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]'' disliked her return for prolonging Will and Emma's separation, branding Holly a home-wrecker. She commented that while Paltrow's appearance in "The Substitute" was "relatively fresh", in "Sexy" she was "acting almost like a cardboard cutout version of her former self, overly enunciating her lines [and] treading carefully around her choreography".{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv/2011/03/09/2011-03-09_glee_season_2_episode_15_recap_sexy_gwyneth_paltrow_is_a_little_frigid.html|title='Glee' season 2 episode 15 recap: 'Sexy' Gwyneth Paltrow is a little frigid|last=Roberts|first=Soraya|date=March 9, 2011|work=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]|accessdate=March 9, 2011|location=New York}} Poniewozik found all of Paltrow's scenes "labored and ridiculous", and wrote that the actress failed to bring an element of realism to her character. Jim Cantiello of [[MTV]] praised Paltrow's performance, calling her "a breath of fresh air."{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1659526/glee-sexy-episode-recap.jhtml|title='Glee'-Cap: Gwyneth Paltrow's 'Sexy' Sub Teaches Us A Lesson|last=Cantiello|first=Jim|date=March 8, 2011|work=[[MTV]]|publisher=[[Viacom]]|accessdate=March 9, 2011}} [[Image:Naya Rivera and Heather Morris.jpg|thumb|left|The developing relationship between Santana (Rivera, ''left'') and Brittany (Morris, ''right'') was well-received by critics.]] The BrittanyâSantana plot received critical acclaim. Gonzalez was somewhat surprised by the storyline, observing that Santana had not previously been portrayed as "so serious and vulnerable", but enjoyed the depth it brought to her character. She and Poniewozik both praised Rivera's acting, with Gonzalez calling her "heartbreakingly perfect". Poniewozik did not find Santana's revelation sudden; he was impressed that the episode found "pathos and heartbreak" in a coupling formerly treated humorously. VanDerWerff deemed it the best storyline of the episode, saying it was almost alone the reason the episode received a "B". He called the scene where Santana confessed her feelings for Brittany one of the best moments of the season. Burns was pleased that the storyline was "treated with a tender realness," something generally lacking on network television, and Brown, though unconvinced that Santana's conflicted sexuality adequately explained her abrasive personality, praised the series for "exploring some of the more complicated aspects of adolescent sexuality", writing that "''Glee'' does an admirable job of attempting to be all-inclusive." The fatherâson relationship between Kurt and Burt also drew positive reviews. de Moraes found it odd that Blaine approached Burt to talk to Kurt about sex, but wrote that their subsequent heart-to-heart was the "closest thing to a satisfying conclusion" the episode had. Fallon called it "one of the most uncomfortable fatherâson sex talks ever committed to television (and thus, really, one of the most realistic)", and Flandez found it sweet. Though Gonzalez deemed it awkward to watch, she wrote that the scene served to convince her she had never loved a father-son pairing more. Poniewozik also found it realistic and moving, giving particular praise to O'Malley for portraying Burt's "determination and awkwardness in helping his son, without turning it into an afterschool special." ==Music== ===Performances=== "Sexy" features [[cover versions]] of five songs: "Do You Wanna Touch Me (Oh Yeah)" by [[Gary Glitter]], as recorded by Joan Jett, "Animal" by Neon Trees, "Kiss" by Prince, an [[Acoustic music|acoustic]] version of "Landslide" by Fleetwood Mac, and "Afternoon Delight" by the Starland Vocal Band.{{Cite web|url=http://www.gleethemusic.com/us/node/12183/|title=Glee Season 2 Episode 15: Sexy - The Official Music for Glee Site|accessdate=March 4, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://music.aol.com/blog/2011/03/08/glee-sexy-recap-season-2-episode-15/|title='Glee,' 'Sexy' Recap -- Season 2, Episode 15|last=Benitez-Eves|first=Tina|date=March 8, 2011|publisher=[[AOL Music]]|accessdate=March 9, 2011}} Paltrow performs on "Do You Wanna Touch Me (Oh Yeah)", "Kiss" and "Landslide". The three tracks were released as singles, available for download,{{cite web|url=http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B002J028S6/|title=Glee Cast: MP3 Downloads|work=[[Amazon.com]]|accessdate=March 5, 2011}} and feature on the series' sixth [[soundtrack album]], ''[[Glee: The Music, Volume 5]]''.{{Cite web|url=http://www.amazon.com/Glee-Music-5-Cast/dp/B004MYG6XA/ |title=Glee: The Music, Volume 5|work=[[Amazon.com]]|accessdate=February 23, 2011}} In the UK, "Do You Wanna Touch Me (Oh Yeah)" was omitted from ''Glee: The Music, Volume 5'', and "Afternoon Delight" was included instead.{{Cite web|url=http://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B004URN5O2/|title=Glee: The Music, Volume 5|work=[[Amazon.co.uk]]|accessdate=April 12, 2011}} A cover of [[Rod Stewart]]'s "[[Da Ya Think I'm Sexy?]]" performed by the Warblers was planned to be featured in the episode but did not appear. The track appears on the soundtrack album ''[[Glee: The Music Presents the Warblers]]'', on which "Animal" is also included.{{Cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/warblers-glee-album-a-track-179498|title=Warblers 'Glee' Album: A Track-by-Track Account From the Beelzebubs|date=April 19, 2011|first=Emily|last=Rome|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=April 22, 2011}} ===Critical commentary and impact=== [[File:Prince at Coachella.jpg||right|thumb|Prince's song "Kiss" was covered.]] Musical performances in the episode attracted mixed commentary. Brown wrote that all the performances "felt a little lackluster [...] though none stood out as being particularly awful." Roberts called the performance of "Do You Wanna Touch Me (Oh Yeah)" a "leather-clad, hair-whipping mess". Gonzalez graded it a "B"; she enjoyed the energy and Morris' dancing, but found it lacking vocally. The inclusion of the song in an episode dealing with sex education and adolescent sexuality sparked some controversy,{{cite web|title=âGleeâ faces Glitter storm|url=http://new.uk.music.yahoo.com/blogs/behind_the_music/47864/glee-face-glitter-storm/|publisher=Yahoo! Music UK & Ireland|accessdate=March 10, 2011}}{{cite news|title=Why Glee's new hit is lining the pockets of Gary Glitter|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/news/why-glees-new-hit-is-lining-the-pockets-of-gary-glitter-2237540.html|accessdate=March 10, 2011|newspaper=The Independent|date=March 10, 2011}} as its original performer, [[Gary Glitter]], is a [[registered sex offender]] in the [[United Kingdom]].{{cite news|title=Glitter jailed over child porn|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/517604.stm|accessdate=March 10, 2011|newspaper=BBC News|date=November 12, 1999}} He has been convicted of several sexual crimes involving minors, including a [[Gary Glitter#Child pornography arrest and conviction|conviction for possession]] of [[child pornography]] in the UK in 1997, and his [[Gary Glitter#Vietnam underage sex conviction|conviction]] for [[child sexual abuse]] in Vietnam in 2005.{{cite news|title=Gary Glitter Sentenced To 3 Years|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2006/03/03/entertainment/main1364881.shtml|accessdate=March 10, 2011|newspaper=CBS News|date=March 3, 2006}} [[Charitable organization|Charities]] dedicated to serving and helping children have filed complaints to Fox and the producers of ''Glee''.{{cite web|title=Gary Glitter Glee song causes complaints|url=http://www.musicrooms.net/tv/28516-gary-glitter-glee-song-causes-complaints.html|publisher=MusicRooms.net|accessdate=March 10, 2011}} Television executives in the UK, where the show is broadcast about a month later than in the US, were rumoured to be considering the removal of the scene entirely. However, a spokesperson for [[Channel 4]] stated that the episode would air in full, and explained: "The scene is editorially justified within the programme and we do not seek to censor material in the proper context."{{cite web|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/03/10/uk-glee-glitter-idUKTRE7296TC20110310|title=Channel 4 to air "Glee" episode with Glitter hit|date=March 10, 2011|publisher=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=March 20, 2011}} Claude Knights, the executive director of the [[London, England|London]]-based children's charity [[Kidscape]], said, "It is regrettable that the producers did not consider the implication of using such a track in the context of a sex education class. The fact that this song is linked to Gary Glitter [...] make[s] it wholly inappropriate".{{cite news|title=Disgraced Gary Glitter song in 'Glee'|url=http://www.torontosun.com/entertainment/tv/2011/03/10/17561186-wenn-story.html|accessdate=March 10, 2011|newspaper=Toronto Sun|date=March 10, 2011}} The UK edition of ''Glee: The Music, Volume 5'' omits the track; "Afternoon Delight" is included instead. Gonzalez gave "Afternoon Delight" a "C". She highlighted its corniness, and wrote that Stamos was wasted on the performance. "Animal" drew generally negative reviews, derided by Roberts as the only element of the episode "less sexy than Paltrow". She called the Warblers' version "hokey". Flandez agreed that they "single-handedly ruin[ed]" the track, likening Kurt's expressions throughout to "[[Jar Jar Binks]] on acid", criticizing his "jerky moves and infantile facial expressions." VanDerWerff criticized it for being "connected to utterly nothing whatsoever". In contrast, Gonzalez gave the number her highest grade of the episode, an "A+". She deemed it "unforgettable", praising the song selection and writing that it met and possibly exceeded her high expectations. Tyler Glenn, lead singer of the Neon Trees, said "I thought it was cool";{{cite web |url= http://www.mlive.com/entertainment/flint/index.ssf/2011/05/neon_trees_find_habits_excitin.html |title=Band Neon Trees finds niche with 'Animal,' 'Your Surrender'|first= Christina|last= Fuoco Karasinski|work=mlive.com |date= 2011-05-20|accessdate=5 June 2011}} bassist Branden Campbell mentioned how [[Darren Criss]] approached the band at the 2011 [[Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival]] thanking them for allowing the song to be used, as Criss was the one who brought the song to Ryan Murphy's attention.{{cite web |url= http://blog.music.aol.com/2011/05/09/neon-trees-interview/ |title=Neon Trees Are Flattered by 'Glee' Attention, Reveal Reason for Covering Justin Bieber's 'Baby'|first= Nicole|last= Pajer|work=blog.music.aol.com |date= 2011-05-09|accessdate=5 June 2011}} [[File:Sexy Glee.png||right|thumb|Performing "Kiss".]] Critics differed over the performance of "Kiss". Roberts praised the "real sex appeal" Morrison brought to the number, but deemed Paltrow's tango rigid. de Moraes observed that neither of them would have progressed past the first week of the reality series ''[[Dancing with the Stars (U.S. TV series)|Dancing with the Stars]]'', and Burns commented that white people ought to be deterred from performing Prince. He called the music "uninteresting and soulless", and was dismayed that the tango was "just white with white people tango dancing." Flandez, however, enjoyed their dancing, writing that "The strong holds, the slow cuts, the perfect swivel of hips and the lean-toâs were mesmerizingly seductive." Gonzales also enjoyed the choreography, but disliked Morrison's falsetto, and wished he has been allowed to sing in his own register throughout rather than imitating Prince. She graded the performance "C+". "Landslide" received a "B+" from Gonzalez, who wished that Rivera, rather than Paltrow, had sung the lead vocal, due to the meaning the song held for Santana. Roberts found the performance "pretty but uninspired". Flandez called it "a dreamy, perfectly pitched power song of lesbian love", Poniewozik "surprisingly poignant", and VanDerWerff named it the best number of the episode. [[Stevie Nicks]] of Fleetwood Mac welcomed the cover of "Landslide", hoping it would bring the band's songs to a new generation. She approved of the performance, and said that Paltrow "sang it beautifully."{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/glee-gwyneth-paltrow-landslide/|title=âGleeâ Cast Feat. Gwyneth Paltrow, âLandslideâ â Song Spotlight|last=Hensel|first=Amanda|date=March 8, 2011|work=Taste of Country|publisher=[[Townsquare Media]]|accessdate=March 9, 2011}} The day that "Landslide" was filmed, Nicks herself visited the set.{{cite web|url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/222326/glee-behind-the-glee-sexy#s-p1-sr-i1 |title=Behind the Glee: Sexy|date=March 9, 2011|work=[[Hulu]]|publisher=[[20th Century Fox Television]]|accessdate=March 9, 2011}} ===Chart history=== {{See also|Glee Cast discography}} Of the five cover versions released as singles, four debuted on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]], and appeared on other musical charts. On the Hot 100, the show's rendition of "Landslide" debuted at number twenty-three;Peak chart positions for season 2 singles in the United States: "Landslide", "Do You Wanna Touch Me (Oh Yeah)", "Animal", and "Kiss" {{Cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/hot-100?chartDate=2011-03-26&order=gainer|title=Hot 100: Week of March 26, 2011 (Biggest Jump)|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=July 5, 2011}} it was at number thirty-five on the ''Billboard'' Canadian Hot 100.{{Cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/canadian-hot-100?chartDate=2011-03-26&order=gainer|title=Canadian Hot 100: Week of March 26, 2011 (Biggest Jump)|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=July 5, 2011}} The other three songs on the Hot 100 were "Do You Wanna Touch Me (Oh Yeah)" at number fifty-seven, which also made number sixty-three on the Canadian Hot 100, "Animal" at number sixty-two, which also made number sixty-five on the Canadian Hot 100, and "Kiss" at number eighty-three, which also made number eighty on the Canadian Hot 100.
